The center of a group $G$ is defined as the centralizer of $G$, i.e., as $Z=Z_{G}=\{x \in G ; x s=s x \text { for all } s \in G\} .$
The symmetric group, denoted as $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$, is the group of all bijective self-maps of the set $\{1, \ldots, n\}$.
Does the concept of a/an Center need to be defined for a definition of a/an Symmetric Group to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a Symmetric Group involves the group of all bijective self-maps of a set, specifically the set of permutations of {1, ..., n}. This definition focuses on the properties and structure of permutations and does not inherently require the concept of a Center. The Center of a group, defined as the set of all elements that commute with every other element in the group, is a concept used to analyze specific properties within group theory, such as the internal structure and behavior of elements in a group. However, the existence and definition of a Symmetric Group do not depend on the concept of a Center. The Symmetric Group can be fully defined and understood without reference to its Center. Thus, the concept of a Center is not necessary for the definition of a Symmetric Group to make sense.
